title-group.article-title: Free vibrations of Timoshenko beam-columns on Pasternak foundations

article-meta.aff: Dipartimento di Ingegneria Civile e Ambientale, Università di Catania, Italy

author-notes.corresp: Annalisa Greco, Dipartimento di Ingegneria Civile e Ambientale, Università di Catania, Viale Andrea Doria 6, 95125 Catania, Italy Email: agreco@dica.unict.it

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper the free vibration and the stability of axially loaded Timoshenko beams on elastic foundation are analyzed through the dynamic stiffness matrix method. The study is carried out considering a two–parameter elastic soil which contains the characteristics of both the Winkler and the Pasternak foundations. The equation of motion and the exact dynamic stiffness matrix of a beam–column including the effect of shear deformation and rotatory inertia is derived. The eigenproblem of the beam–column is therefore solved through the application of the general Wittrick and Williams algorithm. The effects of soil characteristics as well as shear deformations and rotatory inertia on the natural frequencies of the beam-column are investigated. An extensive parametric study highlights the main parameters that characterize the dynamical behavior of the considered beam–column.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Because of its great practical importance for technical engineers, the analysis of the dynamic behavior of beams on elastic foundations has interested many researchers in the last century and has therefore been the object of a huge number of papers since the pioneering studies of Winkler (1867). The Winkler model, which can be viewed as a continuous layer of independent linear springs, constitutes the simplest representation of continuous elastic foundations and is still the most adopted in practical applications. A detailed treatment of this model can be found in the classical text by Hetenyi (1961). In spite of its simplicity the Winkler model cannot adequately represent a continuous medium such as the soil, especially at the free boundaries of the beam, since it overlooks the soil cohesion. For this reason many other mechanical foundation models, which do not feature this limitation, have been presented in the literature and the physical meaning and reliability of each of them has been extensively studied both in the static and in the dynamic case (Razaqpur and Shah, 1991; Franciosi and Masi, 1993). A critical review on idealization and modelling for a soil-foundation-structure system can be found in the paper by Dutta and Roy (2002). Improved foundation models assume a pressure displacement relationship based on two (Wieghardt, 1922; Filonenko-Borodich, 1940; Pasternak, 1954; Vlasov and Leontiev, 1966; De Rosa, 1995; Matsunaga, 1999; Morfidis and Avramidis, 2005; Arboleda-Monsalve et al., 2008) or three parameters (Kerr, 1965; Morfidis, 2007) whose interpretations can be different and in some cases not fully investigated.

It is worth noticing that the two parameters mechanical foundation models proposed by Wieghardt, Pasternak and Filonenki-Borodich, though based on different physical interpretations of the soil-beam interaction, lead to the same expression of the soil reaction (Ylinen and Mikkola, 1967; Anderson, 1976; De Bellis et al., 2010). Furthermore, in most cases the parameters of these more accurate models are not directly related to the soil properties and therefore they are difficult to calibrate for practical purposes. A systematic investigation, together with the development of a methodology for the determination of all the required parameter, has been recently conducted by Avramidis and Morfidis (2006). Further refined mechanical models allow the improvement of the evaluation of the dynamic behavior provided by existing models by introducing a damping source, for example in Engel (1991) where the Winkler, Hetényi and Pasternak foundation are modified to include viscous damping to the supporting medium. Other studies consider the influence of the soil in the boundary conditions of the beams (Filipich and Rosales, 2002) as well as the behavior of the beam on elastic foundations subjected to moving loads (Kargarnovin and Younesian, 2004). A subject of interest is also represented by the stability of beams on elastic media subjected to non-conservative actions. In particular the effect of a Wieghardt elastic foundation on the dynamic stability of a fluid conveying pipe has been investigated by De Bellis et al. (2010).

Except for the Winkler model, the larger part of the free vibration analyses reported in the literature handle with approximate solutions. These are obtained either by solving numerically the frequency equation (De Rosa, 1995) or by using approximate finite element solutions (Franciosi and Masi, 1993; Rajasekhara and Venkateswara Rao, 1995; Yokoyama, 1996) or by mixed approaches (Chen et al., 2004). Explicit formulae for the fundamental natural frequencies of vibration of finite Timoshenko-beams on Pasternak foundations have been derived by El-Mously (1999). An alternative method which determines the exact values of the natural frequencies requires the knowledge of the dynamic stiffness matrix of the beam and is based on the application of the Wittrick and Williams algorithm (Williams and Wittrick, 1970, 1983). This method has been applied by many authors (Oliveto, 1992; Banerjee, 1998, 2001) for different types of beams as well as for beams on elastic foundations. Specifically Williams and Kennedy (1987) provided the exact Bernoulli–Euler dynamic member stiffnesses for a beam on a Winkler-type elastic foundation. Later on, Capron and Williams (1988) provided the exact dynamic stiffnesses coefficients for an axially loaded Timoshenko member embedded in Winkler-type elastic medium and showed how to use them in order to obtain the natural undamped frequencies through the Wittrick and Williams algorithm. Recently an overview article on the possible applications of the algorithm has been provided by Williams and Kennedy (2010).

The aim of the present paper is to evaluate the dynamic stiffness matrix of axially loaded Timoshenko beams on Pasternak-type two–parameter elastic foundations and to carry out a parametric investigation on the free vibration characteristics of a single beam-column. The soil is modelled either as a Winkler or as a Pasternak layer while the beam is represented either as a Timoshenko or as a Bernoulli-Euler element and the differences in the dynamic behaviors, according to these different assumptions, are focused. Particular attention has been devoted to the evaluation of the influence of the dimensionless parameters introduced on the values of the natural frequencies. The dynamic characteristics of the model are also compared with those of the beam with the same boundary condition but non-interacting with the soil, in order to emphasize the soil-structure interaction effects. The presented numerical results confirm those obtained in the literature by means of competing methods.

Although the subject has been widely considered in the literature this theoretical formulation represents a further contribution to the dynamic stiffness method and is used to advantage with Wittrick and Williams algorithm to provide essentially exact results. The knowledge of the dynamic stiffess matrix of the beam-column on elastic foundation in conjunction with the Wittrick and William algorithm allow the exact evaluation of the dynamic and the stability behavior of frame structures interacting with the soil. This investigation may also be useful, in practical soil structure engineering analyses, for the evaluation of reasonable soil parameters according to the simplified Winkler or Pasternak models, by means of experimental dynamic identification procedures.

sec.title: 2. Formulation of the equations of motion
sec.p: As presented by Winkler (1867), the simplest way to model an elastic foundation is to consider a finite number of independent vertical springs whose reaction p(x,t) can be easily expressed as (1)p(x,t)=kwv(x,t) where kw is a characteristic parameter of the soil and v(x,t) the function of the transversal displacements of the beam. Some improved versions of the Winkler model are based on the following two parameter expression for the vertical reaction of the soil (2)p(x,t)=kwv(x,t)-k2v″(x,t)

Specifically, Wieghardt (1922) assumed that the deflection at each point is related to the reaction of all the foundation layer by means of a non-uniform kernel function. Filonenko-Borodich (1940) introduced an evolution of the Winkler model considering an interaction between each individual spring by means of an elastic membrane subjected to a constant tension, which represents the second parameter k2. Later on Pasternak (1954) introduced a two-parameter model in which the second parameter is based on the assumption that there is a shear interaction between the springs.

Starting from a continuous idealization, a further two-parameter expression of the soil reaction has been proposed by Vlasov and Leontiev (1966). Namely considering the soil as a semi–infinite linearly elastic medium he obtained the following expression of the second elastic parameter (3)k2=Es4(1+νs)Bμ where Es and νs are respectively the Young’s modulus and the Poisson’s ratio of the soil, B is the width of the beam and μ is a constant expressing the rate at which vertical deformation of soil decays with depth. The differences between these models are extensively described in the literature (Dutta and Roy, 2002).

In this paper the equation of motion and the dynamic stiffness matrix will be derived in the general case in which the Timoshenko beam-column lays on a Pasternak foundation. The axial deformation is neglected and reference will be made to a second elastic parameter for the soil k2=kp.

Considering the translational and rotational equilibrium conditions of an infinitesimal beam element in its deformed configuration (Figure 1) the following is obtained (4)∂V∂x=m∂2v∂t2+kwv-kp∂2v∂x2 (5)Vdx-∂M∂xdx+N∂v∂xdx-mρ2∂2ψ∂t2dx=0 where V, M and N are respectively the vertical force, the bending moment and the horizontal conservative force acting on the cross section at the abscissa x, ψ is the rotation of this section, ρ2 is the square of the radius of gyration of the beam cross section and m is the uniformly distributed mass per unit length. Figure 1.
Beam element.

The constitutive equations related to the flexural and to the shear stiffnesses may be written in the form (6)M=-EI∂ψ∂x; T=kGAη where T is the shear force orthogonal to the beam axis, E and G are its moduli of longitudinal and transverse elasticity, I and A are respectively the moment of inertia and the area of the cross section, k the shear correction factor and η is the shear deformation angle (Figure 1). The following relation holds between the shear force and the vertical and horizontal forces: (7)V=T-N∂v∂x=kGAη-N∂v∂x
Since η=∂v/∂x-ψ, the equilibrium conditions (4) e (5) in the case of uniform beam become: (8)(kGA-N+kp)∂v2∂x2-kGA∂ψ∂x-m∂2v∂t2-kwv=0 (9)EI∂2ψ∂x2+kGA∂v∂x-kGAψ-mρ2∂2ψ∂t2=0

In order to formulate the equilibrium equation the expression ∂ψ/∂x must be derived from equation (8). This allows the derivatives ∂3ψ/∂x3 and ∂3ψ/∂x∂t2 to be evaluated which substituted in the differentiated form of equation (9) provide: (10)EI(1-NkGA+kpkGA)∂4v(x,t)∂x4 +(N-EIkwkGA-kp)∂2v(x,t)∂x2 +(Nmρ2kGA-mEIkGA-mρ2-mρ2kpkGA)∂4v(x,t)∂x2∂t2 +(m+mρ2kwkGA)∂2v(x,t)∂t2+m2ρ2kGA∂4v(x,t)∂t4+kwv(x,t)=0 which represents the equation of motion of an axially loaded Timoshenko beam on a Pasternak elastic foundation in terms of the displacement function v(x,t). It is easy to verify that the same equation holds in terms of the rotation of the beam by simply substituting v(x,t) with ψ(x,t).

sec.title: 3. The dynamic stiffness matrix
sec.p: In free vibration the displacement v(x,t) can be expressed in the form (11)v(x,t)=φ(x)eiωt where φ(x) is the mode of vibration and ω is the circular frequency.

Introducing the non-dimensional variable ξ=x/L, from equations (10) and (11) the following equation of motion is obtained: (12)EIL4(1-NkGA+kpkGA)∂4φ∂ξ4+1L2(N-kp-EIkwkGA)∂2φ∂ξ2 +1L2(ω2mρ2-ω2Nmρ2kGA+ω2mEIkGA+ω2mρ2kpkGA)∂2φ∂ξ2 -[ω2m+ω2mρ2kwkGA-kw-m2ρ2kGAω4]φ(ξ)=0 which can also be expressed as (13)d4φ(ξ)dξ4+σ2d2φ(ξ)dξ2-a4φ(ξ)=0 where the following dimensionless parameters have been introduced (14)σ2=1br2-π2(n-p)[μ4r2[r2(1+b)-π2(n-p)] +br2π2(n-p)-w]a4=1br2-π2(n-p) [μ4r2(w+br4-μ4)-wbr2] with (15)μ4=mω2L4EI; b=kGE; n=NL2π2EI;r2=L2AI=L2ρ2; w=kwL4EI; p=kpL2π2EI

It is worth noticing that setting p = 0 the equation of motion of a Timoshenko beam on a Winkler foundation is readily obtained while the case of the Bernoulli-Euler beam on elastic soil is acquired when 1/r→0 and 1/b→0.

The general solution of equation (13) may be expressed in the form (16)φ(ξ)=A1sinγξ+A2cosγξ+A3sinhɛξ+A4coshɛξ where (17)γ=σ22+(σ22)2+a4; ɛ=-σ22+(σ22)2+a4 it is worth to notice that the parameters γandɛ can be either real or imaginary numbers.

In order to evaluate the dynamic stiffness matrix the kinematic and static boundary conditions must be imposed. The kinematic boundary conditions are (18)φ(0)=vo φ(1)=v1 ψ(0)=ψo ψ(1)=ψ1 while the static ones are (19)V(0)=-Vo V(1)=V1 M(0)=Mo M(1)=-M1

The flexural rotation, the shear force and the bending moment must therefore be expressed in terms of φ(ξ). After some algebraic manipulations the following expressions can be obtained: (20)Lψ(ξ)=c1dφdξ+c3d3φdξ3 (21)M(ξ)=-EIL2[Coφ(ξ)+C2d2φdξ2] (22)V(ξ)=-EIL2[C1dφdξ+C3d3φdξ3] Where (23)c1=b2r4-w+μ4b(br4-μ4); c3=π2(p-n)+br2b(br4-μ4); Co=μ4-wbr2;C2=π2(p-n)br2+1 (24)C1=-br2(1-bb2r4-w+μ4b(br4-μ4)) -n;C3=br2π2(p-n)+br2b(br4-μ4);

The kinematic boundary conditions may therefore be expressed in the form: (25)[vov1LψoLψ1]=[0101scSCB10B20cB1-sB1CB2SB2][A1A2A3A4]or: u=WA Where (26)B1=(c1-c3γ2)γ; B2=(c1+c3ɛ2)ɛ; s=sinγ;c=cosγ; S=sinhɛ; C=coshɛ

Similarly the static boundary conditions assume the form (27)[VoLV1LMoM1]=EIL2[-B30B40cB3-sB3-B4C-B4S0B50-B6-sB5-cB5SB6CB6][A1A2A3A4]or: f=QA in which (28)B3=-(C1-C3γ2)γ B4=(C1+C3ɛ2)ɛB5=-(C0-C2γ2) B6=(C0+C2ɛ2)

Evaluating the modal constants from equation (25) and substituting in equation (27) the relation between generalized forces and the corresponding displacements can be found (29)[VoLV1LMoM1]=EIL2[δ-δ¯ϑϑ¯-δ¯δ-ϑ¯-ϑϑ-ϑ¯αβϑ¯-ϑβα][vov1LψoLψ1]or: f=QW-1u=K(ω)u where the elements of the dynamic stiffness matrix can be written in the following form (30)α=(B5+B6)(B1sC-B2cS)/Dβ=(B5+B6)(B1S-B2s)/D (31)δ=(B2B3+B1B4)(B1Cs+B2cS)/Dδ¯=(B2B3+B1B4)(B1s+B2S)/D (32)ϑ=[(B1B4-B2B3)(1-cC)+(B1B3+B2B4)sS]/Dϑ¯=B1B2(B5+B6)(C-c)/D with (33)D=2B1B2(1-cC)-(B12-B22)sS

sec.title: 4. Determination of the natural frequencies and modes of vibration
sec.p: J0 is the number of frequencies of vibration of the beam with both ends clamped which are lower than ω*. In the present paper the number J0 has been evaluated by means of the same method proposed by Howson and Williams (1973) and by Capron and Williams (1988).

The equation of the generic mode of vibration is given from equation (16) once the modal constants have been evaluated. This can be achieved from equation (25) (35)A=W-1u where the elements of the matrix W-1 must be calculated as functions of the evaluated frequency of vibration and the nodal displacements depend on the supports of the beam.

sec.title: 5. Numerical applications
sec.p: Several numerical applications have been conducted with reference to beam–columns on different elastic foundations in order to highlight the main parameters that characterize their dynamical behavior. In the following only a selection of the obtained results is reported for brevity. In each figure the trend of the first two natural frequencies of vibration is studied when one of the previously defined characteristic parameters is considered as a continuous variable in a significant range while all the other parameters are assigned.

Figure 2 shows the influence of the slenderness of the beam on the first two natural frequencies of vibration. As it is well known the Timoshenko model approaches the Bernoulli–Euler one, characterized by dashed lines, for high values of the ratio r2 while for small values of the slenderness ratio notable differences between the two models can be observed. The differences are more pronounced for the second frequency. Figure 2.
Variation of natural frequencies of simply supported Timoshenko beams on an elastic soil with the slenderness parameter.

In order to take account of significant contributions of shear deformability and rotational inertia in the following, reference will be made to r2 = 400 which refers to squat beams such as a short tubular pile with the following geometrical characteristics: diameter 30 cm, thickness 1 cm, length 2 m.

Figure 3 shows how the shear deformability parameter b influences the first two natural frequencies of vibration. A shear correction factor k = 2(1 + ν)/(4 + 3ν) has been assumed for the considered thin-walled round tube (Cowper, 1966). A significant range for engineering applications for the parameter b has been calculated considering the Poisson’s ratio of the material variable in its reference range. It can be noticed that the frequencies of the Timoshenko beam increase with the shear deformability parameter and the differences with the Bernoulli-Euler model are once again more pronounced for the second frequency. Figure 3.
Variation of natural frequencies of simply supported Timoshenko beams on an elastic soil with the shear deformability parameter.

In Figures 4(a) and (b) respectively the first and the second frequencies of vibration of a simply supported beam on elastic foundation are reported, as a function of the compressive axial force, until the critical value is reached. In order to separately evaluate the effects of the two characteristic parameters of the soil, in the same figures the natural frequencies of the beam non-interacting with the soil and of the beam on a Winkler foundation are also reported. Furthermore the effects of the shear deformability and of the rotational inertia on the fundamental frequencies of vibration are indicated by a comparison with the frequencies of the Bernoulli-Euler beam on the same elastic foundation. The latter can be calculated by means of the Wittrick and Williams algorithm simply setting 1/r→0 and 1/b→0 in the evaluation of the dynamic stiffeness matrix. Nevertheless, in the following, the frequencies of the Bernoulli-Euler beam have been calculated by means of a closed-form solution reported by Caliò and Elishakoff (2004), obtained as a particular case of a special class of inhomogeneous beam-columns on elastic foundation. Namely in the case of a uniform simply supported Bernoulli-Euler beam-column on two–parameters elastic foundation the natural frequency can be obtained by the expression (36)ωj2=j2π2(j2π2EI+kPL2-NL2)+kWL4mL4 Figure 4.
Variation of natural frequencies of vibration of a simply supported Timoshenko beam with the axial force.

From the observation of the numerical results, it can be seen that, with reference to the considered characteristics of the beam and the soil, the frequency parameters, μ4, for the Timoshenko beam-columns depend almost linearly on the axial force. Furthermore the frequencies of the Timoshenko beam-column are always lower than the corresponding Bernoulli-Euler ones, for each foundation assumption, and once again the difference is more pronounced for the second frequency.

Figures 5(a) and (b) show the effects of the Winkler soil parameter on the first two natural frequencies of a Timoshenko simply supported beam on elastic foundation. It can be noticed that the frequency value increases almost linearly with the stiffness of the Winkler soil and only for the second frequency are there notable differences between the Bernoulli-Euler and the Timoshenko models. The curves clearly show the reduction of the frequencies of vibration of the Timoshenko beam with respect to the Bernoulli-Euler ones due to shear deformability and rotational inertia. Figure 5.
Variation of natural frequencies of a simply supported Timoshenko beam with the characteristic parameters of Winkler soils.

Figures 6(a) and (b) show the effects of the Pasternak soil parameter on the first two natural frequencies of a Timoshenko simply supported beam on elastic foundation. Figure 6.
Variation of natural frequencies of a simply supported Timoshenko beam with the characteristic parameters of Pasternak soils.

Since no experimental data pertaining the shear foundation parameter p are available, a range of significant values has been taken from Valsangker and Pradhanang (1988) in which reference is made to the simplified elasticity approach (Vlasov model). In this range both the first and the second frequencies increase linearly with the foundation parameter with a small slope. The reduction of the frequencies of vibration of the Timoshenko beam with respect to the Bernoulli-Euler ones is once again observed.

With the aim of validating the proposed numerical results against those obtained from competing methods in the literature, in Table 1 a comparison with the results obtained by Yokoyama (1996) through a finite element approach is reported. Namely the first three natural frequencies for a Timoshenko beam-column obtained by Yokoyama considering eight or 16 elements in the beam are compared with those obtained by the proposed procedure. From the analysis of the results reported in the table it can be recognized a very good agreement between the exact results, obtained by the proposed approach, and the ones obtained by Yokoyama. It is worth noticing that the finite element approach gives an upper approximation of the frequencies. Table 1.
Comparison of the first three natural frequencies of a simply supported Timoshenko beam obtained by the proposed procedure and by Yokoyama (b = 0.2, n = 0.6, r2 = 100, p = 1, w = 58.445)
Proposed procedure Yokoyama* 8 elements Yokoyama* 16 elements
First frequency 12.64 12.65 12.64
Second frequency 28.02 28.34 28.10
Third frequency 45.92 47.61 46.34
*
Yokoyama (1996).

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: In the paper the free vibration of Timoshenko beam-columns on Pasternak elastic foundation are analyzed by means of the dynamic stiffness matrix method. The equation of motion of the beam–column and the exact dynamic stiffness matrix have been derived and the corresponding exact eigenvalue problem has been solved through the Wittrick and Williams algorithm (Williams and Wittrick, 1970). The effects of soil characteristics as well as shear deformation and rotational inertia in the free vibration of a simply supported beam-column have been investigated and the results have been compared with those obtained by means of the Bernoulli- Euler model.

The proposed methodology allows the exact evaluation of the frequencies and the buckling loads of beams on two–parameters Pasternak–type elastic foundation and can also be useful in practical soil–structure engineering analyses for the evaluation of reasonable soil parameters that must be assumed according to Winkler or Pasternak model by means of experimental dynamic identification procedures. Namely a sample beam can be tested with and without the interaction with the soil and the corresponding frequencies can be identified. Therefore, by using a dynamic identification procedure the corresponding soil parameters can be evaluated according to the desired model.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are grateful for the support of their funding body.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Italian MURST (grant number 2008–2009).
